channel.title: Array
channel.description:
Dear moparscape,
[code]c.playerEquipment[c.playerCape] == AttackSkillCapes[0][/code] [code]public int Array[] = {5, 5, 5};[/code] Let's say we want to add Skillcapes. I make an array with all the skillcape id's like the example. Is it possible to call the index, all 3 at the same time? Instead of making something like: [code]AttackSkillCapes[0] || AttackSkillCapes[1] || AttackSkillCapes[2][/code]
Thanks in advance, Halflive9

item.title: Array
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“lare69, post:11, topic:545210”][quote author=Dan0194 link=topic=664092.msg4439355#msg4439355 date=1406048319]

you really shouldn’t convert an array to a list to a hashset just to use a convenient .contains function

You don’t have to convert it to a set really just if you have duplicates and you want them gone you could convert it into a list anyways I never said it was better I said it looked cleaner it’s just an alternative if you want.
[/quote]
standard list would be fine for this, although with more elements using a hash set would be smart because of the O(1) time complexity for the contains function[/quote]it has 10 objects in it, i doubt efficiency is an issue regardless of implementation…

Read full topic

You don’t have to convert it to a set really just if you have duplicates and you want them gone you could convert it into a list anyways I never said it was better I said it looked cleaner it’s just an alternative if you want.[/quote]

item.title: Array
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

[quote=“halflive9, post:6, topic:545210”][quote author=ohokay link=topic=664092.msg4439048#msg4439048 date=1405959303]
Assuming that you just want to check whether or not the player is wearing a skill cape, you could use something like this.

public int[] skillcapes = { 1, 2, 3 };

public boolean cape(int itemId) {
	for (int i : skillcapes) {
		if (i == itemId) 
			return true;
	}

	return false;
}

Usage

if (cape(wearId)) { . . . }
[/quote]

This would be good solution.

What I’m trying to do is to check with an if statement if the cape is in my list of skillcapes.

if (playerEquipment[playerCape] == SkillCape's) { DoSomething(); }[/quote]

So you could re-write the above to work something like…

if (cape(playerEquipment[playerCape])) { doSomething(); }

This would check if the player cape is in your skillcape list, then you’d need to check level requirements and whatever else.

Read full topic
